questions.question: What was Alice doing at the beginning of the story?

options.A: Reading a book with her sister
options.B: Sitting by her sister on the bank

questions.explanation: Alice was sitting by her sister on the bank, getting tired of having nothing to do.

questions.question: What color eyes did the White Rabbit have?

options.B: Red

questions.explanation: The story describes 'a white rabbit with pink eyes' running close by Alice.

questions.question: What did the White Rabbit take out of its waistcoat pocket?

options.B: A fan

questions.explanation: The rabbit took a watch out of its waistcoat pocket and looked at it.

questions.question: What was the name of Alice's cat?

options.B: Dinah

questions.explanation: Alice's cat was named Dinah, whom she mentions missing during her fall.

questions.question: What label was on the bottle Alice found on the glass table?

options.B: Eat Me

questions.explanation: The bottle had a paper label with the words 'Drink Me' beautifully printed in large letters.

questions.question: What was written on the cake Alice found?

options.B: Eat Me

questions.explanation: The words 'Eat Me' were beautifully marked in currants on the cake.

questions.question: What type of cat is the Cheshire Cat?

options.B: A Cheshire cat belonging to the Duchess

questions.explanation: The Duchess tells Alice 'It's a Cheshire Cat' when Alice asks why it grins.

questions.question: Who was smoking a hookah on top of the mushroom?

options.B: The Dodo

questions.explanation: Alice found a large Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom, smoking a long hookah.

questions.question: What were the gardeners painting the roses?

options.B: Red

questions.explanation: The three gardeners were busily painting the white roses red.

questions.question: What did the Queen frequently shout?

options.B: Guards, seize them!

questions.explanation: The Queen constantly shouted 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!' about once a minute.

questions.question: What were used as croquet balls in the Queen's game?

options.B: Hedgehogs

questions.explanation: In the Queen's croquet game, the balls were live hedgehogs.

questions.question: What were used as croquet mallets?

options.B: Flamingos

questions.explanation: The mallets were live flamingos that Alice had to tuck under her arm.

questions.question: What animal did the Duchess's baby turn into?

options.B: A dog

questions.explanation: The baby gradually turned into a pig while Alice was carrying it.

questions.question: Who was always falling asleep at the tea party?

options.B: The March Hare

questions.explanation: The Dormouse was sitting between them fast asleep and kept dozing off throughout.

questions.question: What did the Mock Turtle used to be?

options.B: A real turtle

questions.explanation: The Mock Turtle said with a deep sigh, 'Once I was a real turtle.'

questions.question: What did the Knave of Hearts steal?

options.B: Some tarts

questions.explanation: The accusation read: 'The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts.'

questions.question: How tall was Alice when she was too small to reach the key?

options.B: Ten inches

questions.explanation: After drinking from the bottle, Alice was only ten inches high.

questions.question: Who organized the Caucus Race?

options.B: The Duck

questions.explanation: The Dodo said 'the best thing is to get us dry would be a Caucus Race' and organized it.

questions.question: What did Alice give as prizes after the Caucus Race?

options.B: Comfits (candies)

questions.explanation: Alice pulled out a box of comfits from her pocket and handed them round as prizes.

questions.question: Who was Bill in the story?

options.B: A guinea pig

questions.explanation: Bill was a lizard who was sent down the chimney and later was a juror at the trial.

questions.question: When Alice drank from the bottle, she found it tasted like ---.

options.A: water with a hint of lemon
options.B: a mixed flavor of cherry tart, custard, pineapple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast

questions.explanation: The drink had 'a sort of mixed flavor of cherry tart, custard, pineapple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast.'

questions.question: The Pool of Tears was created when ---.

options.B: Alice cried while she was nine feet tall
options.D: the Caterpillar made it with magic

questions.explanation: Alice realized 'she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.'

questions.question: The Mouse became angry with Alice because she kept mentioning ---.

options.B: the White Rabbit

questions.explanation: The Mouse got upset when Alice mentioned her cat Dinah and then a dog, saying 'our family always hated cats' and swimming away from talk of dogs.

questions.question: The Caterpillar told Alice that one side of the mushroom would make her grow taller and ---.

options.A: the other side would make her invisible
options.B: the other side would make her grow shorter
options.C: the top would make her fly
options.D: the bottom would make her disappear

questions.explanation: The Caterpillar said 'One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.'

questions.question: The Pigeon accused Alice of being ---.

options.A: a thief trying to steal eggs
options.B: a serpent because of her long neck

questions.explanation: When Alice's neck stretched very long, the Pigeon screamed 'Serpent!' and accused her of coming to eat eggs.

questions.question: At the Mad Tea Party, the Hatter asked Alice ---.

options.B: why a raven is like a writing-desk

questions.explanation: The Hatter asked 'Why is a raven like a writing-desk?' as a riddle with no answer.

questions.question: The Hatter said it was always six o'clock because ---.

options.B: he had quarreled with Time
options.D: the March Hare stopped all clocks

questions.explanation: The Hatter said 'he won't do a thing I ask' about Time, ever since they quarreled at the Queen's concert.

questions.question: The gardeners were painting the roses red because ---.

options.B: they had planted a white rose tree by mistake and would be beheaded if the Queen found out

questions.explanation: The gardener explained 'this here ought to have been a red-rose tree, and we put a white one in by mistake, and if the Queen was to find out, we should all have our heads cut off.'

questions.question: The Cheshire Cat's most distinctive feature was that it could ---.

options.B: disappear leaving only its grin behind

questions.explanation: The cat 'vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.'

questions.question: The Duchess kept saying everything has ---.

options.B: a moral

questions.explanation: The Duchess said 'everything's got a moral, if only you can find it' and kept adding morals to everything.

questions.question: The Mock Turtle called his teacher 'Tortoise' because ---.

options.B: he was very slow
options.C: he taught us (taught-us sounds like tortoise)

questions.explanation: The Mock Turtle said angrily 'We called him Tortoise because he taught us.'

questions.question: The subjects at the Mock Turtle's school included ---.

options.B: reeling, writhing, and uglification

questions.explanation: The Mock Turtle said they learned 'Reeling and Writhing' and 'Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.'

questions.question: When Alice grew large in the Rabbit's house, the White Rabbit thought she was ---.

options.B: his housemaid Marianne

questions.explanation: The Rabbit called out 'Why, Marianne, what are you doing out here?' and Alice thought 'He took me for his housemaid.'

questions.question: The Dormouse's story was about three sisters who lived ---.

options.A: in a castle in the sky
options.B: at the bottom of a well

questions.explanation: The Dormouse began: 'Once upon a time there were three little sisters... and they lived at the bottom of a well.'

questions.question: At the trial, when asked for evidence, the cook said tarts are made mostly of ---.

options.B: pepper

questions.explanation: When the King asked 'What are tarts made of?' the cook said 'Pepper, mostly.'

questions.question: The King's Rule 42 stated that ---.

options.A: all witnesses must tell the truth
options.B: no one may speak without permission
options.C: all persons more than a mile high must leave the court

questions.explanation: The King read 'Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.'

questions.question: When Alice kicked Bill up the chimney, the others outside said ---.

options.B: There goes Bill!

questions.explanation: After Alice kicked, she heard a general chorus of 'There goes Bill!'

questions.question: The pebbles thrown at Alice through the window turned into ---.

options.B: flowers

questions.explanation: Alice noted 'that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor.'

questions.question: The Gryphon told Alice that the Queen ---.

options.A: was the kindest ruler in the land
options.B: never actually executes anybody

questions.explanation: The Gryphon chuckled and said 'They never execute nobody, you know.'

questions.question: The Lobster Quadrille was a dance that involved ---.

options.B: throwing lobsters into the sea and swimming after them

questions.explanation: The Mock Turtle described throwing lobsters 'as far out to sea as you can' then 'swim after them.'

questions.question: Why does Alice question her own identity throughout the story?

options.A: She has amnesia from the fall
options.B: The constant physical changes make her feel like a different person
options.C: The Queen cast a spell on her
options.D: She is pretending to be someone else

questions.explanation: Alice says 'being so many different sizes in a day is very confusing' and wonders 'who in the world am I?' after her transformations.

questions.question: What does the Caucus Race satirize?

options.B: Political processes where everyone wins and nothing is accomplished

questions.explanation: The race has no clear rules, no defined winner ('Everybody has won, and all must have prizes'), satirizing pointless political activities.

questions.question: Why is the Mad Tea Party 'stuck' at six o'clock?

options.B: Time has stopped because the Hatter offended Time at the Queen's concert
options.C: They prefer having tea at that time
options.D: The March Hare cast a spell

questions.explanation: The Hatter quarreled with Time at the Queen's concert, and since then Time won't help him, so 'it's always six o'clock' - always tea-time.

questions.question: What is ironic about the Queen's justice system?

options.A: She is too lenient with criminals
options.B: She orders executions constantly but they are never carried out
options.C: She lets Alice make all the decisions

questions.explanation: Despite shouting 'Off with their heads!' constantly, the Gryphon reveals 'They never execute nobody' - her threats are empty.

questions.question: What does Alice's statement 'You're nothing but a pack of cards!' represent?

options.B: Her recognition that the authority figures have no real power over her

questions.explanation: Alice finally realizes the threatening figures are just cards with no real authority, showing her growth in confidence and understanding.

questions.question: Why does the Caterpillar's question 'Who are you?' frustrate Alice?

options.B: She has changed so much she genuinely doesn't know anymore
options.D: She is hiding her true identity

questions.explanation: Alice says 'I hardly know, sir... I know who I was when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.'

questions.question: What does the Mock Turtle's sadness despite having 'no sorrow' suggest?

options.A: He is pretending to be sad
options.B: Emotions in Wonderland are performed rather than genuinely felt
options.C: He has forgotten why he was sad
options.D: The Gryphon is lying about him

questions.explanation: The Gryphon says 'It's all his fancy, that. He hasn't got no sorrow' - suggesting emotions in Wonderland are theatrical performances.

questions.question: What criticism of education is made through the Mock Turtle's school?

options.B: Schools are too expensive
options.C: Education is full of confusing wordplay with questionable practical value

questions.explanation: The punning subjects like 'Reeling and Writhing' instead of 'Reading and Writing' mock how education can be confusing and seemingly meaningless.

questions.question: What does the trial scene satirize about the justice system?

options.B: Evidence and logic are often ignored in favor of authority and absurdity

questions.explanation: The trial is absurd: the jury writes before evidence, the Queen wants 'sentence first - verdict afterwards,' and meaningless verses are treated as key evidence.

questions.question: Why does Alice's size constantly change throughout the story?

options.B: It symbolizes the confusing physical and emotional changes of growing up

questions.explanation: Alice's size changes represent the confusing experience of childhood, where one feels 'too big' for some things and 'too small' for others.

questions.question: What does the Duchess's obsession with finding 'morals' in everything mock?

options.A: People who read too many books
options.B: The Victorian tendency to attach forced moral lessons to everything

questions.explanation: The Duchess's forced, nonsensical morals ('the more there is of mine, the less there is of yours') parody Victorian children's literature that insisted every story have a moral.

questions.question: Why does Alice check if the bottle is marked 'poison' before drinking?

options.B: It shows she applies real-world logic even in an illogical world
options.C: Her sister warned her about strange bottles
options.D: The White Rabbit told her to check

questions.explanation: Alice 'remembered the simple rules' about not drinking from bottles marked poison, showing she tries to apply sensible childhood rules to Wonderland's nonsense.

questions.question: What does the Cheshire Cat's statement 'we're all mad here' suggest about Wonderland?

options.B: Madness is relative and what seems normal depends on where you are

questions.explanation: The Cat suggests madness is the norm in Wonderland, implying that 'sanity' depends on context - Alice is 'mad' by Wonderland standards too.

questions.question: Why does the Mouse's 'long and sad tale' become a visual pun?

options.A: The Mouse is crying while telling it
options.B: Alice confuses 'tale' with 'tail' and imagines it shaped like a mouse's tail
options.C: The story is written in a sad tone

questions.explanation: Alice looks at the Mouse's tail and mishears 'tale' as 'tail,' imagining the story text curving down the page like a tail.

questions.question: What is significant about the Hatter's riddle having no answer?

options.B: It reflects how Wonderland's logic doesn't require things to make sense
options.C: Alice was supposed to make up the answer
options.D: The March Hare knew the answer but wouldn't tell

questions.explanation: When Alice asks for the answer, the Hatter says 'I haven't the slightest idea' - in Wonderland, questions don't require sensible answers.

questions.question: What is the effect of adults in Wonderland constantly giving Alice contradictory orders?

options.A: It helps her learn to follow instructions
options.B: It mirrors how children experience adult authority as arbitrary and confusing
options.C: It makes her a better person
options.D: It teaches her to be obedient

questions.explanation: Alice thinks 'Everybody says come on here... I never was so ordered about in all my life' - reflecting how adult commands can seem random to children.

questions.question: Why does Alice wake up at the moment she defies the Queen?

options.B: Her sister woke her up for tea
options.C: Standing up to authority breaks the dream's hold on her

questions.explanation: Alice wakes when she says 'You're nothing but a pack of cards!' - asserting herself against arbitrary authority ends her passive dreaming state.

questions.question: What does the croquet game's chaos represent?

options.B: The impossibility of playing by rules when the rules keep changing arbitrarily

questions.explanation: With live hedgehogs, flamingos, and moving arches, and 'no rules in particular,' the game shows how arbitrary authority makes fair play impossible.

questions.question: Why does Alice's sister's daydream at the end repeat elements from Alice's adventure?

options.A: She fell asleep and had the same dream
options.B: It shows how stories and imagination connect people across generations
options.C: Wonderland is a real place both can visit

questions.explanation: The sister imagines the same scenes, suggesting how Alice's story (and childhood wonder) will be passed on, keeping 'the simple and loving heart of her childhood.'

questions.question: What is the ultimate message about childhood in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland?

options.B: Childhood is meaningless and should be forgotten
options.C: Childhood wonder and questioning should be preserved even as we grow up
options.D: Dreams are dangerous and should be avoided

questions.explanation: The ending hopes Alice 'would keep through all her riper years the simple and loving heart of her childhood' - preserving childhood's curious, questioning spirit.
